TypeSignature.Value: public delegate void FormClosedEventHandler(object sender, FormClosedEventArgs e);
.class public auto ansi sealed FormClosedEventHandler extends System.MulticastDelegate
Public Delegate Sub FormClosedEventHandler(sender As Object, e As FormClosedEventArgs)
public delegate void FormClosedEventHandler(System::Object ^ sender, FormClosedEventArgs ^ e);
type FormClosedEventHandler = delegate of obj * FormClosedEventArgs -> unit

Docs.param: A that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Represents the method that handles a event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.FormClosed> event occurs after a form is closed, either by the user, through the user interface (UI), or programmatically, through calls to methods such as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Close%2A> in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> class, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application.Exit%2A> in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application> class.
When you create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.FormClosedEventHandler> delegate, you identify the method that will handle the event. To associate the event with your event handler, add an instance of the delegate to the event. The event handler is called whenever the event occurs, unless you remove the delegate. For more information about event-handler delegates, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
